_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Compressors, condensers vessels, pumps, piping, evaporators

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
I. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:

A. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
     Driscoll Strawberry Associates, Inc. currently has in place the following policies and procedures 
     designed and implemented to minimize the risk of an accidental release of ammonia and to describe   
     the proper response to an emergency situation.
       1. Driscoll Strawberry Associates, Inc., Emergency Response Plans and Procedures 
       2. Exclusive Use of Trained Operators On All Refrigeration Equipment on a Daily Basis.
       3. Employee Training Checklist.  
       4. Pre-Cool Safety Inspection Report.  .
       5. Employee Safety Meeting Sign-In Sheet.  .
       6. Annual Refrigeration System Inspection.  .
       7. Daily Compressor Log Sheet
.  .
B. General Facility Information
  1. FACILITY LOCATION
      The Driscoll Strawberry refrigeration facility is located near the Community of Aromas, on the coast
      of central California, near the northwestern border of Monterey County, on 31.32 acres of property.
      The  facility is located at 1750 San Juan Road.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is all
      agricultural land, and is bordered on the northwest side by the Southern Pacific Railroad.
      Driscoll Strawberry Associates, Inc. has been growing, cooling and storing strawberries on this
      location for the last  27 years.  The current Driscoll Strawberry facility was built in the late 1960's, and
      has been using ammonia refrigeration since that time.
      The new construction project consists of  a 60,000 sq. ft.  pre-cooling and cold storage warehouse
      with a dedicated ammonia refrigeration system.  The new construction is located adjacent to, and just
      south of, the previously existing Driscoll Cold Storage warehouse and office complex.  The proposed
      new AHM equipment will be installed on the west side of the new building.  The new equipment
      consists of 11 room cooling evaporators, 14 pre-cooling u

nits, 4 auto coolers, an engine room, plus the 
      related piping system and controls.  All of which will be permanently installed at this facility and totally 
      independent from the previously existing buildings and equipment.
     The total quantity of ammonia to be used in the refrigeration system will be approximately 9,300 lbs.  
     The piping and instrumentation diagram for the refrigeration process is shown in the Appendix.  The 
     AHM used in this system is anhydrous ammonia, and it is used as the primary refrigerant in a closed-
     loop system.  Therefore, the containment of the ammonia within the piping/equipment system is the key 
     to eliminating accidental releases.  
 2. PREVENTION OF SYSTEM OVERCHARGING
     See Operating Procedures Section VI.D.1.C. 
 3. UTILITY SYSTEM
     The facility has an emergency power system to respond to possible power failures.  The failure of 
     such a system to operate in an emergency poses no risk of an ammonia release since loss of power 
     simply stops the flow of ammonia, however electrically operated pumps, etc., may be affected.
     In the event of a post-earthquake fire at the site, firewater is drawn from the facility's on-site well and 
     reservoir system.  The post-earthquake functionality of the facility's firewater system thus depends on 
     the vulnerability of the system to earthquake-induced failure, which is unknown.

C. Release Scenarios
     The worst case release scenario to be considered is as specified in 2750.3.C.1) which is 100% of the 
     system charge released in 10 minutes.  The analytical results of this scenario are found in Section 4, 
     however, it is highly unlikely that a release of this magnitude could ever be realized due to the physical 
     characteristics of ammonia.
     The alternate release scenario chosen concerns a ruptured 4" liquid ammonia pipeline.  This scenario is 
     possible during an earthquake and has the most serious impact of the tr

uly possible scenarios.    
     Existing administrating controls to be used in the event of a release are contained in the "Emergency 
     Response Plans and Procedures", under Emergency Response Steps / Mitigation and Abatement.  A 
     copy of the E.R.P.P. is included in the appendix
     Mitigation of Ammonia Releases is addressed by the following
       1. System Design and Construction
       2. Administrative Controls
       3. Equipment Testing and Maintenance Procedures
       4. Ammonia Detection and Alarm System
       5. Refrigeration System Control Hardware
       6. Operating Engineer On-Site Daily
       7. Off-Hours Security Service
       8. A Release Inside the Building Would Require Closing the Building Doors

 D. General Accidental Release Prevention Program
     The particular AHM to be considered is anhydrous ammonia.  The general accidental release prevention 
     program consists of the following:
       1.    System Design and Construction
       2.    Administrative Controls
       3.    Equipment Testing and Maintenance Procedures
       4.    Hiring Qualified Operators
       5.    On-going Training of Operators
       6.    Ammonia Detection and Alarm System
       7.    Refrigeration System Control Hardware
       8.    Operating Engineer On-Site Daily
       9.    Off-Hours Security Service
       10.    Daily Inspections Of Refrigeration System
       11.    The Main Emphasis is to Keep the Ammonia Inside the System
       12.    This is a Single Chemical System.

 E. Ammonia Release History
     Driscoll Strawberry Associates, Inc. has not experienced an ammonia release within the last 5 years 
     that has resulted in any of the following:
       1.    Off-site Consequences
       2.    Personal Injury     
       3.    Property Damage
       4.    Facility Evacuation
       5.    Environmental Damage

F. Emergency Response Program
     Driscoll Strawberry Associates, Inc. currently has an existing "Emergency Response Plan and 
     Procedures" manual.  See Appendix.

G. RMP Sub

ject
     The subject of this RMP is a new facility.  It incorporates all of the planned changes to improve safety 
     that have been considered for the original facility.
